content.description:
Start sitting as for "

South Arete

, V3". After gaining the sloping jugs down low, move out right to nice incuts, and finish up the south face.
content.location: Start on the southwest arete of the boulder.

content.description:
Start sitting low on the arete with a right-facing, lieback holds. Make the first move (crux) and the climb eases up as you get higher. Continue following the arete until the

Graduation Crack

finish or make the more natural topout 3/4 of the way up the arete.
content.location: This ascends the South (upstream creek side) arete of the boulder.

content.description: The Graduation Crack is a good crack with a horn at the topout. Its 10-15 degree overhang adds to the challenge.
content.location: It is on the North side of the boulder.

content.description:
Route 4 is in the photo. It is my favorite route on the boulder. Sit start on a big, barely sloping jug, and move up using small crimps on the face and big holds from the

Graduation Crack

. It is super fun and a touch harder than the

South Arete

.
content.location:
Start directly below the overhanging arete to the climber's left of the

Graduation Crack

.

content.description: This is a good route. It is labeled as "route 3" on Mountain Chalet's (good climbing store in The Springs) website.
content.location: It is on the East side of the boulder.

content.description: Start at the obvious chalked holds at the lower right end of the rail/edge feature. Traverse to the last good holds on the rail, and climb straight up to finish.
content.location: It ascends the right side of the south/creekside face.

content.description: Pull on to the slab on the southeast face. Either traverse right underneath and around the small roof, or mantel straight through on good holds. Finish up on good edges and crystals.
content.protection: Pads. A fall from at/above the small roof would be oof.
content.location: On the left (southeast) side of the boulder when viewed from the trail, this is on the "Post-Graduation Boulder" on the hillside across the creek and above the roadside "Graduation Boulder". Follow the trail to approach Tinseltown Gully/Sun Slabs, but stay on the main trail heading further up canyon until this highball is right next to you.

content.description:
Stand start just left of the northwest arete (left of

Graduation Crack

, just off the road). Reach up, and crimp hard, then use a left hand pinch to bump straight up to a jug, and finish.
content.location: It ascends the left side of the western-most roadside arete. Just pull over.

content.description: Start on a big sidepull ,and work through a couple jugs past the overhang.
content.location: On the farthest right side of the south/creekside face, climb the obvious, small, overhanging bulge on good holds.

content.description: Start right of the arete on the creekside at two left-facing sidepulls. Climb a couple moves into a jug.
content.location:
It is just right of the "

V3 Arete

" creekside.

content.description:
Do the same start as

Graduation Crack

, but go out up right to the pinches on the arete and finish slightly right of

Graduation Crack

.
content.location: This ascends the West face of the boulder.

content.description: This is a nice, slabby climb with a mix of different holds. The hardest parts are the press to the 3-finger pocket and then the couple moves back down. The point of this route is to not use the larger jug holds overhead and only the small pocket. This rock has been climbed every way you can imagine. This is just my personal favorite route to the crack.
content.location:
Sit start of problem #2, move up to the left crimp then to 2 small holds to the right. Press up to the 3 finger pocket crack, and then start making your way over and down to the bottom. Move to the right towards the

Graduation Crack

start then shoot straight up to the horn finish of the crack.
